Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Harpocrates or Harpocratis seated on the ground, the legs extending to the right. He or she wears a long feminine tunic with short sleeves. The curls are luxuriant and include a side-lock; there is a wreath of leaves and a Double Crown. A finger reaches to the mouth and the left hand rests on a pot. The right leg is lost, together with any trace of a phallus. Except for some raised areas, the back is plain. Two-piece mould. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt, with a brown surface. Traces of a white dressing, mainly on the front. A large lump of plaster underneath may be ancient, but probably held the object on a modern stand, the red paint of which extends onto the figure.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Bequeathed by J. Woodhouse, resident in South Italy and Corfu. Ptolemaic, second to first century BC. Comparandum. Near (head only): Petrie 1905: pl. xlviii:57, from House N at Herakleopolis Magna, dated (Petrie and Currelly 1905: 27) third century AD; my date (p. 4) is much the same, but suggests residual Ptolemaic material.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3055)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2006-present, Glasgow, Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum, LT Loan Ancient Egypt British Museum Partnership Gallery
